dimensions.name: perceived_engineering_competence
dimensions.description: Subjective feeling of being a capable, skilled engineer who can solve hard problems and build things that work. The core psychological outcome - inferred from patterns of successful deep technical engagement, problem resolution, and mastery-oriented behavior.

dimensions.name: deep_technical_exploration
dimensions.description: Intensity of focused, rabbit-hole style technical learning. Measured by sequential searches on related technical concepts (e.g., physical unclonable functions → consensus algorithms → composability), following citation chains, and sustained engagement with complex topics over multiple hours.

dimensions.name: academic_resource_engagement
dimensions.description: Access to scholarly/research materials - sci-hub, ResearchGate, arXiv, university PDFs, conference proceedings. Indicates serious engagement with cutting-edge knowledge beyond Stack Overflow solutions.

dimensions.name: work_debugging_activity
dimensions.description: Active problem-solving on real engineering challenges. Measured by searches for error messages, stack traces, library-specific issues (e.g., 'ruby custom stacktrace', 'sentry show post body'). Indicates hands-on coding work.

dimensions.name: problem_resolution_success
dimensions.description: Whether debugging/problem-solving sessions show resolution patterns - moving from error searches to implementation searches, or session ending without repeated frustrated searches. Indicates successful problem solving.

dimensions.name: topic_coherence
dimensions.description: How focused vs scattered the day's technical activity is. Measured as inverse entropy of search topics. High coherence = deep dive into one domain (functional programming). Low coherence = jumping between unrelated topics.

dimensions.name: distraction_browsing
dimensions.description: Non-technical, non-work browsing - travel planning, entertainment, casual curiosity, social searches. May reflect escape from frustration or simply life balance. Measured by count of clearly non-technical searches.

dimensions.name: morning_technical_activity
dimensions.description: Technical search/visit activity during morning hours (6am-12pm). Morning deep work on demanding topics may be particularly valuable for competence feelings due to higher cognitive resources.

dimensions.name: language_tool_exploration
dimensions.description: Exploration of programming languages, paradigms, and tools (Haskell, Scala, OCaml, monads, functional programming). Indicates investment in foundational CS knowledge beyond immediate work needs.

dimensions.name: total_search_volume
dimensions.description: Overall volume of search/browsing activity regardless of type. Baseline engagement level - very low may indicate illness, vacation, or depression; very high indicates active day.

dimensions.name: is_weekend
dimensions.description: Whether the day is Saturday or Sunday. Affects time availability, work pressure, and opportunity for exploratory vs deadline-driven learning.

dimensions.name: cognitive_energy
dimensions.description: Available mental resources for demanding intellectual work. Latent capacity that enables or constrains deep technical engagement. Depleted by stress, poor sleep, sustained effort; restored by rest.

dimensions.name: learning_drive
dimensions.description: Active motivation to learn and explore technical topics beyond immediate job requirements. Intrinsic curiosity activation level - the urge to understand deeply rather than just solve and move on.

dimensions.name: mental_wellbeing
dimensions.description: Overall psychological health state. Evidence of mental health concerns in data (psychiatrist searches). Lower wellbeing reduces capacity for demanding cognitive work and intrinsic motivation.

dimensions.name: health_seeking_activity
dimensions.description: Searches related to mental/physical health, doctors, psychiatrists, symptoms. Observable indicator of wellbeing concerns.

dimensions.name: baseline_intellectual_curiosity
dimensions.description: Trait-level disposition toward intellectual exploration and understanding complex systems. Time-stable individual difference evident in consistent pattern of deep technical rabbit holes across years.

dimensions.name: mastery_orientation
dimensions.description: Trait-level preference for deep understanding and mastery over quick task completion. Orientation toward learning goals rather than performance goals. Stable personal characteristic.

dimensions.name: entrepreneurial_motivation
dimensions.description: Interest in startups, building products, resourcefulness. Observed in Y Combinator searches, Paul Graham readings, startup history. May compete with or complement pure technical mastery orientation.

edges.description: Deep technical rabbit holes require sustained cognitive resources. Low energy days see shallow browsing; high energy enables multi-hour focused exploration of complex topics.
Mental energy enables sustained focus on a single domain. Depleted cognitive resources lead to scattered, jumping-around browsing patterns.
Tackling hard debugging problems requires available mental resources. Low energy may lead to avoidance of difficult technical challenges.
Active curiosity motivates the pursuit of understanding beyond immediate needs. High learning drive leads to following citation chains, reading papers, exploring tangential concepts.
Motivation to truly understand drives seeking primary sources - papers, PhD theses, original research - rather than just blog posts and Stack Overflow.
Interest in programming language theory and paradigms (Haskell, monads, referential transparency) stems from drive to understand computation deeply.
Focused attention on a single domain enables deeper exploration. Coherent sessions build on each search; scattered sessions never reach depth.
Successfully going deep on hard technical topics directly builds competence feelings. Understanding physical unclonable functions or monads creates mastery experience.
Reading and understanding academic papers signals (to oneself) serious engineering capability. Engaging with research-level content builds identity as competent engineer.
Active debugging effort is prerequisite for resolution. More debugging activity increases likelihood of finding solutions.
Successfully solving real engineering problems directly builds competence feelings. The debugging-then-resolution cycle is core to engineering self-efficacy.
Understanding programming language theory and advanced paradigms builds deep competence. Knowing why Haskell needs monads for IO makes one feel like a serious engineer.
Technical work in morning hours, when cognitive resources peak, may be more effective for building competence feelings than late-night frustrated debugging.
Time spent on travel planning, entertainment searches displaces time available for deep technical work. Contemporaneous tradeoff within the day.
Weekends may restore cognitive resources through reduced work pressure. Or deplete them through different activities. Direction unclear but relationship exists.
Weekends provide uninterrupted time for exploratory learning without work deadlines. The PUF/blockchain exploration happened on a Friday-Saturday span.
Weekends naturally have more non-work browsing - travel planning, entertainment, leisure curiosity.
Poor mental health depletes cognitive resources available for demanding work. Depression, anxiety reduce capacity for sustained intellectual effort.
Mental wellbeing affects intrinsic motivation. Depression diminishes curiosity and interest in exploration; good mental health enables active learning drive.
Seeking mental health care (psychiatrist searches) may improve wellbeing over time, or high activity indicates current low wellbeing. Bidirectional indicator relationship.
Feeling competent yesterday increases motivation to learn today. Success breeds engagement; incompetence feelings lead to avoidance.
Low competence feelings lead to escape behavior - seeking distraction the next day. High competence creates positive engagement spiral.
Competence feelings are energizing; feeling incompetent is exhausting. Yesterday's competence experience affects today's available cognitive resources.
Cumulative learning effect - yesterday's deep exploration continues to build competence feelings today as knowledge consolidates.
Trait curiosity manifests as daily learning motivation. Stable disposition toward intellectual exploration activates situation-specific learning drive.
Curious people naturally engage in more deep technical exploration. The consistent rabbit-hole pattern across years reflects stable trait.
Trait curiosity drives seeking primary sources and academic materials rather than surface-level explanations.
Preference for deep understanding drives engagement with scholarly sources where real depth exists.
Mastery-oriented individuals focus deeply on single domains rather than shallow breadth. Trait shapes daily attention patterns.
Interest in programming language fundamentals reflects mastery orientation - wanting to understand computation itself, not just use tools.
Interest in building products and startups may complement or compete with pure technical mastery as source of competence feelings.
Startup motivation may drive practical learning (what's needed to build) but potentially reduce pure intellectual exploration.
Intense debugging sessions deplete cognitive resources. Heavy debugging today reduces available energy tomorrow.
Higher overall activity level provides more opportunity for deep exploration to emerge. Baseline engagement is prerequisite for depth.
Poor mental health directly undermines competence feelings regardless of actual technical activity. Depression distorts self-perception.
